title: Have you ever seen a black Asian? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, this is a native born Shanghainese African-American Han-Chinese. Her name is Jing Lou. I think she is half Nigerian or something, and like Barack Obama, proving once again the indisputable fact that all race and ethnicity are social construction created by people on the fly to distinguish each other.   (This is a Chinese girl) She is as Chinese as they come. Went to Chinese elementary, middle and high school and is now looking for a job as someone who is interested in becoming something other than an English teacher.   She went on a Chinese singing competition called "Go Oriental Girls" and instantly drew the attention of approximately 1.3 billion people, that is 1,300,000,000 people (not including those who are overseas), 3 times the population of US. This is just to highlight how tiny our perspective actually is, as most people in the US can't even name one black asian aside from Tiger Woods. I was in China when her story came out. She didn't win but got pretty far into the competition. Her singing was average. You can sample it here:  (The host kept referring to her as "chocolate girl" - is this racism or not in a country where blacks aren't historically oppressed?) Her story is extremely fascinating and provoked a deep race debate in China. Initially when her story came out there was a great deal of curiosity, then some of it turned discriminatory (mostly from online commentors, I've never heard of any physical provocation against her), then at last the majority of Chinese media outlets turned this into a feel good story, reaching a conclusion that "modern China is made by of all races and Lou Jing is just as Chinese as anybody else". From her perspective, she said in a quote that she was shocked that racism existed in China, how thought provoking is that! Maybe the Chinese do place a higher value on language/linguistic commonality than racial commonality. She also said that children of mixed asian-white parents aren't subjected to the same level of racism as she did, this should be another opportunity for one to ponder the nature of whiteness and what it means to be white.   (Jing and her biological mother) For those who are interested in social studies, I encourage you to read it at the earliest opportunity: Lou Jing and radical is relative and see

Yes. There are dark-skinned people found throughout the southern parts of Asia. Time to introduce the ‘black’ people of Pakistan. The Siddi.  The Siddi are descendants of African migrants over the centuries in South Asia. They are believed to be descended from the Bantu people from East Africa. Found in both Pakistan and India, there are about half a million in total. About half of them live in Pakistan in the provinces of Sindh and Balochistan. The arrival of these people in South Asia began in the late 7th century as traders in the region of Gujarat. That would explain the Siddi population in the region now. The second wave came as soldiers serving in the army of the young Arab general Muhammad Bin Qasim during the early 8th century. Many East Africans came later on as the Mughal Emperors special military guard. Sadly, the final migration was a forced one. The Portuguese traders brought in East Africans as slaves with them to the Subcontinent. Now irrespective of their origins, they form one of the many minority ethnic groups in South Asia.  The majority of the Siddi in Pakistan live in the Makran coastal region and lower Sindh adjacent to the Arabian Sea. The Siddi in Pakistan are generally divided into four clans/houses. These being Kharadar Makan, Hyderabad Makan, Lassi Makan and Belaro Makan. Interestingly, the word ‘makan’ literally means house in Urdu. A very large Siddi population lives in Karachi, the largest city in Pakistan.  The Siddi community in Karachi The Siddi culture is a mixture of their ancestral East African culture and the local Islamic culture. Nowhere is this as visible as it is in Karachi. Just outside of Karachi is Manho Pir, a town the contains the shrine of the Sufi saint Haji Syed Sakhi Sultan. Here the African roots of the Siddi really come to life. Hundreds of them gather at this Sufi shrine and sing Swahili songs and dance to this language that is now barely understood.   Dancing and singing at Mangho Pir  Praying at the Sufi shrine The most interesting thing about Mangho Pir are definitely the crocodiles. The shrine contains crocodiles that are honored every year. It is believed that by doing this the next year will be blessed and will be filled with happiness and prosperity. According to the legend, the lice on the great Sufi saint’s head were transformed into the crocodiles that now live in Manghopir.    The crocodiles of Manghopir  The festival at Manghopir The Siddi community have developed their own unique cultures over the centuries, even unique from each other. Those that lived near the major cities largely assimilated into the local cultures. Others that lived in remote regions, like the escaped slaves that fled to the forests still retain large parts of their ancestral East African culture.    Different types of Siddi dances Last year was an especially good year for the Siddi community in Pakistan. Tanzeela Qambrani joined the Sindh Provincial Assembly as a member of Pakistan People’s Party (PPP) and in doing so became the first Siddi to hold such an office.  Tanzeela Qambrani Another famous member of the Siddi community is Abid Brohi, a singer/rapper. Abid’s life is pretty much the plot of the movie Slumdog millionaire. From an errand boy that used to bring people tea to one of the most famous music artists in Pakistan.  Some Siddi people of note in history are: Yakut Khan - A naval commander that served both the Bijapur Sultanate and the Mughal empire. Hoshu Sheedi Qambrani - A military commander in Sindh who held off the British advance into Sindh till his last breath.  “We will die but not give Sindh to others” -Hoshu Sheedi Jamal-ud-Din Yaqut - A slave who became a noble during the rule of the Delhi Sultanate. He may also have been the lover of Razia Sultana, the only female ruler of the Delhi Sultanate. The Siddi are not the only black people found in Pakistan. Too many people associate black with African and vice versa. Not all Africans are black, nor have they been historically. The North Africans prove this point. Not all black people are Africans. There are many people in South Asia that are just a dark skinned as Sub-Saharan Africans. Yet they are not considered black in the modern meaning of the word. We need to stop associating skin color with ethnicity or nationality.

I find the attitude/thought in the West that “black” people must mean people of recent African ancestry extremely silly, given that the definition merely means people of a dark skin tone. Not to mention it is wrong. Therefore, in this answer I will attempt to show you “black” people whose ancestors haven't been to Africa in thousands of years and who are more related to the “non-black” people of Asia and current African-origin people. Especially, because it seems that nobody has touched this topic yet here. Starting with South Asia, Firstly, many dravidian origin people in India, especially in the southern parts of India,  Dravidian language speaking people were the group that first settled the Indian subcontinent. They are still more related to Indians with lighter skin than they are to any Africans. This definitely does not mean that just because someone speaks such a language, that they will be dark skinned. Many people who speak Indo-European languages are also the same. And most Indians don't differ too much in ancestry. Secondly, the people of the various Andaman tribes of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands in India.   (The two people in the front in the above photo are not Andamanese) Then, the Sentinelese people in the same group of islands. (Who came in the news recently)  There isn't a better picture of them, as they are not to be contacted. But unlike what many in the media would have you believe, they are not war-loving, unless you do something bad to them. Mind you, all the above people are more related to other South/Southeast Asian people than they are to anyone else, including anyone from Africa. : Onge - Wikipedia Now, going on to Southeast Asia, we have Orang Asli people.  Next on the island of New Guinea, we have all the numerous Papuan people.  There you have it, the “black” people of Asia, who are wholly native to Asia.

Yes, of course. Have you seen me? Am I not dark-skinned enough?  I am Ambonese, one of the ethnic groups in Indonesia. The original Ambonese is actually a mixture of Southeast Asian and Melanesian. [1] This is how classic Ambonese would look like.  [2] This is the hunters, nomad war  [3] Ambonese ladies in older era. Most of my aunties look like them. Though the picture is black and white, but you can tell they have dark skin. The eastern part of Indonesia people have dark skin, just like mine. Most of them actually have big eyes, thick eye brows and very long eye-lashes. My eyes are slightly almond-shaped, a little bit different than most of my family members. My eye brows are also not as thick as theirs. My eye-lashes are as long as theirs but not as thick as my brother’s eye-lashes. Most of the foreigners even thought I might be African or Jamaican, while my students confused me as Indians. LOL Footnotes[1] Ambonese - Wikipedia[2] Ambonese, Indonesia. | hunters warriors & nomads | Pinterest | Indonesia, Sejarah indonesia and Dutch east indies[3] Ambonese women going to church, Maluku. Date unknown. | HITAM PUTIH | Pinterest | Old photos, Indonesia and Dutch east indies

response.answer_text: Yes. They are called the NEGRITO PEOPLE. They are the first indigenous inhabitants of a wide swath of territory ranging from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, South East Asia and the island of New Guinea. I'm from the Philippines. Negrito tribes like the Aeta of Luzon, the Ati of Visayas and the Ata of Mindanao looks like this:      There is no doubt they are black. It can't be denied that they are Asian. Therefore, my brethren are Black Asians.

I probably have but didn’t notice, because most will either end up looking black or asian. But I googled it and found one beauty who looks exactly 50/50 imo:  Her eyes are asian and her nose is black, her skin is like a perfect blend of asian plus black skin. In fact it’s like the top half of her face is asian and the bottom half is black.  Her name is Chanel Iman. From 10 Famous (Blasian) Half Black Half Asian Celebrities (the rest of them either look black or asian, but not both)

The Andamanese, including the isolated tribe of North Sentinel Island, are one of the first inhabitants of Southeast Asia that have migrated out of Africa.  They live in the Andaman Islands, the islands are now administered by India.  They are one of the last remaining populations of the Negrito peoples, the original inhabitants of Southeast Asia, prior to the migrations of the Austronesians, Austro-asiatic, Tai, and Burmese Peoples (Modern majority Southeast Asians) from East Asia.  Images and References: Andamanese - Wikipedia Death of American missionary could put this indigenous tribe's survival at risk Andaman Islands - Wikipedia

Haven't we all? Here's a fellow who's often identified as "black" but is also Thai, Chinese and caucasian, who you might remember - golfer Tiger Woods.    And in this week's headlines, Miss Universe Japan 2015, Ariana Miyamoto, who has a Japanese mother and an African-American father.Washington Post: Why some critics think Japan’s Miss Universe contestant isn’t Japanese enough
Ariana Miyamoto.   Her mother is Japanese, and her father is African-American. She won the title of Miss Universe Japan 2015.
Yes.They are not uncommon in Jamaica, where I lived for nearly two years.
